TITLE: Hailstones may get bigger as the climate warms — bringing higher insurance costs
SUMMARY: Hail has caused higher damage costs in the U.S. this year than hurricanes and floods put together. Research suggests climate change will make hailstones larger

TITLE: Even desert plants known for their resilience are burning and dying in the heat
SUMMARY: Agave and saguaro cacti, both heat-tolerant and drought-resistant, are suffering as climate change makes heat waves more frequent and intense

TITLE: Phoenix weathers 100 days of 100-plus degree temperatures
SUMMARY: Unseasonably high temperatures are expected across the western U.S. this week, with an excessive heat warning forecast for Wednesday through Friday in Arizona cities including Phoenix

TITLE: Deep-water murder mystery leads scientists to a novel type of shark-on-shark predation
SUMMARY: Researchers tracking pregnant porbeagle sharks uncovered the first evidence of the species getting eaten by something even bigger

TITLE: Affluent coastal community near L.A. is a geological ticking time bomb
SUMMARY: The land under Rancho Palos Verdes had been slowly giving way for hundreds of years. Now, that movement is accelerating due to heavy rainfall

TITLE: The world just endured the hottest summer on record
SUMMARY: “This string of record temperatures" could also see 2024 logged as the hottest year on record, said EU’s Copernicus Climate Change Service

TITLE: The moon had active volcanoes into the dinosaur age, study finds
SUMMARY: Three glass beads brought back by a Chinese spacecraft indicate there was lunar volcanic activity until about 120 million years ago, much more recently than previously believed

TITLE: Boeing's uncrewed Starliner returns to Earth, capping months of drama in space
SUMMARY: After a summer of turmoil, Boeing’s Starliner spacecraft successfully returned to Earth on Friday without any astronauts onboard

TITLE: SpaceX's Polaris Dawn mission crew completes first all-civilian spacewalk
SUMMARY: Billionaire entrepreneur Jared Isaacman and SpaceX engineer Sarah Gillis ventured out into the vacuum of space early Thursday and made history

TITLE: After Starliner's return, Boeing officials remain noticeably quiet
SUMMARY: Two Boeing officials were expected to participate in a briefing after the Starliner landed back on Earth. But at the last minute, neither appeared

TITLE: The mysterious case of a 650-foot tsunami witnessed by no one
SUMMARY: The tsunami, one of the largest ever recorded, was the result of a series of rare, cascading events set in motion by melting ice

TITLE: 'Supermoon eclipse' will be visible across North America on Tuesday
SUMMARY: People in North America, South America, Africa and Europe will have a chance to see part of the moon’s surface obscured by Earth’s shadow

TITLE: SpaceX capsule splashes down after history-making Polaris Dawn mission
SUMMARY: Splashdown was logged at 3:36 a.m. ET in the Gulf of Mexico off Florida's Dry Tortugas islands

TITLE: Microplastics found in the human brain
SUMMARY: The tiny scraps of plastic were found in the olfactory bulb, the part of the brain responsible for processing smell

TITLE: Titan submersible hearing begins as questions over what went wrong linger
SUMMARY: The Coast Guard’s Marine Board of Investigation will hear two weeks of testimony from former employees of OceanGate, the company that operated the doomed vessel

TITLE: OceanGate CEO put profits over safety ahead of Titan's fatal voyage, ex-employee says
SUMMARY: "The whole idea behind the company was to make money," former Marine Operations Director David Lochridge testified. "There was very little in the way of science

TITLE: Led by the South, clean energy sector added more than 150,000 jobs last year
SUMMARY: The Inflation Reduction Act has fueled job growth in the clean energy industry, which employs nearly 3.5 million people in the U.S., a new report found

TITLE: As extreme weather forecasts get better, warnings struggle to cut through
SUMMARY: Scientists with the National Weather Service and the National Hurricane Center began sounding the alarm for Helene as early as Sept. 23

TITLE: American scientists among chemistry Nobel winners for pioneering protein work
SUMMARY: Half the prize was awarded to David Baker “for computational protein design,” while Demis Hassabis and John Jumper shared the other half “for protein structure prediction

TITLE: The numbers behind Hurricane Helene's rapid intensification as Milton follows suit
SUMMARY: The high sea surface temperatures that have helped both storms intensify were 200 to 500 times more likely because of climate change, the researchers found

TITLE: The science behind why people think they're right when they're actually wrong
SUMMARY: A new study illustrates the saying, "you don't know what you don't know

TITLE: Why Milton could become one of the most destructive hurricanes on record
SUMMARY: Because of the way storm surge can quickly inundate coastal locations and penetrate well inland, it’s typically one of the deadliest threats from a hurricane

TITLE: Hurricane Milton's downpour around Tampa Bay was a 1-in-1,000-year rain event
SUMMARY: St. Petersburg had 18.31 inches of rain — or more than 1.5 feet — in 24 hours

TITLE: Northern lights may be visible Thursday as far south as Alabama and Northern California
SUMMARY: The geomagnetic storm is the most severe since the one that led to dramatic auroras in May

TITLE: Solar storm brings spectacular Northern Lights to sky-watchers as far south as Texas
SUMMARY: Strong solar storm brought dazzling natural phenomenon to rare parts of the world late Thursday and early Friday, lighting up the night sky with vibrant tones of pink and green

TITLE: Why this environmental prize winner sees her clean air advocacy as 'personal'
SUMMARY: Goldman Environmental Prize winner Andrea Vidaurre was born and raised in California’s Inland Empire, a freight hub east of Los Angeles ranked as the nation’s worst in air quality

TITLE: As Florida reels, focus turns to restoring power, assisting victims in Hurricane Milton's wake
SUMMARY: Flooding is still possible in parts of the state as river levels are expected to continue rising into next week

TITLE: NASA launches mission to icy Jupiter moon thought to harbor a vast ocean
SUMMARY: NASA's Europa Clipper probe will study Jupiter's moon Europa, which is thought to have an underground ocean and a potentially habitable environment

TITLE: SpaceX catches Starship rocket booster in dramatic landing during fifth flight test
SUMMARY: The FAA issued SpaceX a license to launch Starship’s fifth flight Saturday, sooner than it had estimated

TITLE: Fifty well-preserved Viking-era skeletons are discovered in Denmark
SUMMARY: Experts hope to conduct DNA analyses and possibly reconstruct detailed life histories, as well as look into social patterns in the Viking Age

TITLE: Foot of a famed Mount Everest climber is possibly found after 100 years
SUMMARY: If confirmed by DNA, the discovery would be the first evidence of Andrew "Sandy" Irvine’s remains

TITLE: Secret underground tomb with 12 skeletons is found in Jordan's Petra
SUMMARY: Researchers who used ground-penetrating radar also discovered an extensive array of grave offerings beneath the ancient Treasury building

TITLE: Meteorologists say they're facing pushback like never before, despite highly accurate forecasts
SUMMARY: Meteorologists have been falsely accused of steering hurricanes toward Florida or Appalachia, and some have reported threats of violence or personal attacks online

TITLE: Half of all global food threatened by growing water crisis, report says
SUMMARY: Densely populated areas such as northwestern India, northeastern China and southern and eastern Europe will bear the brunt of water mismanagement, according to the Global Commission on the Economics of Water

TITLE: Photo contest reveals strange beauty of the microscopic world
SUMMARY: Nikon's annual Small World competition showcases images of a world that humans can't usually see, as captured through the lens of a microscope

TITLE: The evolutionary history of humans' ability to eat starch
SUMMARY: The gene for amylase, which helps break down foods like pasta and potatoes, has a longer evolutionary history than scientists previously thought

TITLE: Winter weather forecast: Wetter than average for the Northwest and Great Lakes, NOAA says
SUMMARY: For the rest of the country, it predicts an average or warm and dry winter

TITLE: Phoenix ends 21-day streak of record October heat
SUMMARY: The Southwest has been contending with unseasonably warm autumn temperatures 10 to 20 degrees Fahrenheit above average

TITLE: Bird flu cases in people quietly tick up, with dozens reported across 6 states
SUMMARY: Four cases in Washington farmworkers are the latest in a drumbeat of human infections across the U.S. as the virus continues to spread among farm animals

TITLE: A giant, ancient meteor four times the size of Mount Everest may have sparked life on Earth
SUMMARY: The S2 meteorite, discovered in 2014, was four times the size of Mount Everest and unleashed a tsunami bigger than any in known human history

TITLE: After weeks of weather delays, NASA astronauts and Russian cosomonaut finally leave space station
SUMMARY: The crew was scheduled to return to Earth more than two weeks ago, but inclement weather — including Hurricane Milton — kept the four members in space longer than planned

TITLE: Hong Kong discovers dinosaur fossils for the first time
SUMMARY: Initial analysis showed that the fossilized bone belonged to a large dinosaur from the Cretaceous period, though the exact species remains unknown

TITLE: NASA astronaut hospitalized after return from space station
SUMMARY: The space agency did not share the astronaut's name or the nature of their medical issue

TITLE: Skeletal remains in a castle well lend credence to a centuries-old Norse saga
SUMMARY: The new findings, using advanced DNA analysis, connect the identity of the remains found at Norway's Sverresborg castle to a passage in a medieval text called the Sverris Saga

TITLE: Vast ancient Mayan city is found in a Mexican jungle — by accident
SUMMARY: The site, dubbed "Valeriana," was found under jungle canopy using drone mapping technology known as LiDAR.&nbsp

TITLE: Back from the dead: Scientists rebuild the face of 400-year-old Polish 'vampire'
SUMMARY: A team of scientists has reconstructed Zosia’s face, revealing the human story buried by supernatural beliefs in an unmarked cemetery in Pien in northern Poland

TITLE: The race to solve the mystery of 'ghost particles'
SUMMARY: Inside an advanced Chinese facility designed to measure neutrinos — the smallest subatomic particles known to physicists

TITLE: Halloween chills are out as record-high temperatures are expected across the country
SUMMARY: Conditions in many parts of the U.S. on Thursday are expected to be 10 to 30 degrees warmer than average

TITLE: A monkey writing Shakespeare? That's much ado about nothing, scientists claim
SUMMARY: The Infinite Monkey Theorem is "grossly misleading in the real world," one of the Australian mathematicians behind a new study questioning the age-old maxim told NBC News

TITLE: Already in political crosshairs, fates of NOAA and FEMA hang in the election balance
SUMMARY: Government weather and disaster agencies have become increasingly politicized, so the election may be pivotal to their futures. Project 2025 recommends major changes and cuts to NOAA and FEMA

TITLE: Special mud rubbed on all MLB baseballs has unique, 'magical' properties, study finds
SUMMARY: For decades, baseball has relied on mud from one secret location to help players better grip balls. No one had explained the science behind it — until now

TITLE: Drought plagues majority of Northeast as dry, windy weather raises fire risk
SUMMARY: October ended as one of the driest months on record in the U.S. Cities such as Philadelphia; Newark, New Jersey, and Norfolk, Virginia, recorded no rain at all

TITLE: New Jersey declares drought warning and urges residents to reduce water use
SUMMARY: The dry conditions are part of a broader drought across the Northeast. Nationally, October was one of the driest months on record

TITLE: Parched fields and damaging blazes: The Northeast drought and wildfires in photos
SUMMARY: More than 58% of the Northeast is in moderate drought or worse, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor.&nbsp

TITLE: World's largest coral found 'hiding in plain sight' near Solomon Islands for 300 years
SUMMARY: Looking like a shipwreck from the surface, the gigantic organism is large enough to fit two full-size basketball courts side by side

TITLE: The truth is out there: Pentagon's annual report reveals hundreds of new UFO sightings
SUMMARY: The report was published a day after the second major hearing on UAPs was held in Congress, where leaders called for greater transparency from the Pentagon on UAP knowledge

TITLE: Ecosystem predating the dinosaurs uncovered in the Alps by a hiker and melting snow
SUMMARY: The discovery, made public Wednesday, includes well-preserved footprints of reptiles and amphibians that scientists say date back 280 million years

TITLE: 35,000-year-old frozen saber-toothed cat mummy studied for first time ever
SUMMARY: The cat's remains were found in Yakutia, Russia, and were determined to be those of a 3-week-old cub

TITLE: Editor-in-chief of Scientific American steps down after anti-Trump comments
SUMMARY: The magazine’s top editor wrote several profanity-laced social media posts about the results of the election

TITLE: Beaver moon, last supermoon of the year, and Leonid meteors to light up sky on same weekend
SUMMARY: The beaver moon will reach its peak on Friday and the Leonid meteor shower will be on full display on Saturday

TITLE: A mythical harbinger of doom washes up on a California beach
SUMMARY: A rare oarfish, believed to portend disaster, washed up on a beach in Encinitas last week. Since 1901, only 21 oarfish have been recorded on California's shores. This is the second this year

TITLE: Trump watches Musk's SpaceX rocket launch in Texas
SUMMARY: Trump is a relatively recent convert to the potential value of SpaceX’s services, having mocked Musk’s “rocketships to nowhere” in 2022

TITLE: Chemical identified in drinking water likely to be in many homes and could be toxic, study finds
SUMMARY: The substance is a byproduct of the process of treating water with chloramine, a chemical used to kill viruses and bacteria. It’s not yet known whether it is dangerous

TITLE: SpaceX completes sixth Starship flight, with both booster and spacecraft splashing down
SUMMARY: SpaceX typically has a cadre of VIPs to view Starship launches and, with CEO Elon Musk’s close relationship with President-elect Donald Trump, the sixth flight was no different

TITLE: Vaccines don't cause autism. What does?
SUMMARY: Scientists say most brain changes that contribute to autistic traits occur before birth

TITLE: Environmental groups prepare to fight a new Trump administration
SUMMARY: Leading environmental advocacy organizations say a second Trump term is something they’ve been preparing for, and they’re ready to litigate

TITLE: Researchers capture baleen whales for the first time to study their hearing
SUMMARY: The study on two juvenile males comes amid concern about the effects of ocean noise on some of the largest and most intelligent animals on Earth

TITLE: Cold plunge or a hot bath? New study suggests which has more benefits for athletes
SUMMARY: A new small study suggests that hot water can help muscles repair themselves and become stronger

TITLE: Contentious COP29 deal shows climate cooperation fraying at edges
SUMMARY: Geopolitical turmoil and worries of a looming U.S. withdrawal from global climate cooperation loomed large in Baku and will continue to overshadow global climate efforts in the months ahead

TITLE: Animal rights extremist wanted for U.S. bombings caught after decades on the run
SUMMARY: Daniel Andreas San Diego is accused of setting off homemade explosives at two Northern California companies he believed were conducting animal experiments

TITLE: NASA astronaut Suni Williams talks Thanksgiving plans in space — and says she's not 'stranded'
SUMMARY: The space station crew will feast on smoked turkey, apple cobbler, green beans, mushrooms and mashed potatoes, Williams told NBC News in an interview from orbit

TITLE: Scientists gather to decode puzzle of the world's rarest whale
SUMMARY: The careful study of the creature — which washed up dead on a New Zealand beach in July — is the first ever

TITLE: Killer whale spotted balancing a salmon on its head, intriguing scientists and orca watchers
SUMMARY: Orcas were previously seen sporting salmon on their heads in the late 1980s. It’s not clear what the behavior means

TITLE: Asteroid on 'collision course' with Earth burns up above far northeastern Russia
SUMMARY: Residents in the Russian republic of Yakutia were treated to a light show as the asteroid harmlessly burned up

TITLE: Mysterious illness in Congo has killed dozens of people, health authorities report
SUMMARY: An unidentified disease has killed 79 people and sickened 376, according to the Democratic Republic of Congo's Ministry of Public Health, Hygiene and Social Security

TITLE: Trump picks billionaire Jared Isaacman to lead NASA
SUMMARY: Isaacman has flown to space twice on commercial SpaceX missions but hasn't worked in the federal government

TITLE: Invasive 'murder hornets' found in Europe for the first time
SUMMARY: Researchers think the southern giant hornets likely made a nest, but they are still looking for it

TITLE: Why has it been even hotter than expected recently? Research points to diminishing cloud cover
SUMMARY: Global temperatures in the last two years have been higher than scientists anticipated. That may be because cloud cover has decreased, a study suggests

TITLE: California earthquake: Tsunami warning canceled after 7.0-magnitude quake
SUMMARY: The earthquake ruptured off California’s coast at about 10:45 a.m. PT, according to the U.S. Geological Survey

TITLE: NASA says moon mission is further delayed but hopes to land astronauts before China
SUMMARY: The next Artemis mission, which will send four astronauts on a flight around the moon, will be delayed until 2026, NASA announced. The program is already years behind schedule

TITLE: 7.0 earthquake in Northern California knocks out power to thousands
SUMMARY: The earthquake rumbled at around 10:44 a.m. local time about 62 miles west of Ferndale, California, according to the U.S. Geological Survey
